It's like trying to paint a house while they're building it. Of course, if it takes 3 years to build and you're living in it at the time maybe you'd like a little paint here and there...

I personally disagree that waiting to balance things until everything is done is a good idea, let alone necessary. I think "balance" can not be attained in a bubble and that it often requires additional systems in order to attain. Only balancing at the end results in basically having to make do with what you have and precludes the possibility that what you planned ahead of time might not be any fun. IMO, until something *is* fun you're just operating on a theoretical level that may or may not pan out.

So, to me, incrementally balancing things as you go is generally a better approach as it allows you to raise the alarm when systems just aren't working right, when you may need new ones, when the ones that are there should be scrapped in favor of something else, or when you realize that plans that you had really aren't necessary or serve any real purpose (which is what I tend to suspect about the conversion system).

In the worst case you may even realize that something new you just added in actually makes the game less fun, but without any form of existing balance, there won't be any real way to tell if that's the case.

I've put a lot of work into trying to balance career mode since science was first introduced and certainly don't feel any of my previous work was wasted with the introduction of these new systems. Additional variables have been introduced into the equation for sure, but that just means I can focus on tweaking them in isolation around the base that I've already established instead of being overwhelmed by the overall complexity of the situation.

The issue with the space centre scene is that feature discoverability is low. I've seen posts here suggesting that the names of the buildings should be displayed somewhere. This is due to the current hover/toolbar system having low visibility. There are alternatives. For example, add floating labels to the buildings, or a sidebar of buttons listing all the buildings.

Low GUI discoverability is an issue throughout the game. Hover-controlled elements are particularly problematic. An integrated interactive tutorial focusing on both GUI and mechanics could deal with this, and reduce the incidence of commonly seen problems such as probes failing due to low power. This should begin automatically on creating the first game in any mode, and have the ability for experienced players to skip it in the introduction. Automatically beginning is important as new players often don't see optional tutorials in their rush to begin having fun.

The tutorial mode could either be made a full guided tour, bringing the player around each scene, or consist of individual independent scene-specific tutorials triggered by the first entry to any given scene. In keeping with the current GUI theme, an GUI element consisting of an animated kerbal guide with accompanying text could be overlaid onto the window. For the space centre, a description of each building would be given with the building highlighted, and the ability to leave the scene locked during this. KSP is near-simulator in terms of what needs to be learned, so the tutorial should be comprehensive. In general, flashing, highlighting or drawing a line should be used to draw the player's attention to each GUI element in turn.

The tutorial mode could either be made a full guided tour, bringing the player around each scene, or consist of individual independent scene-specific tutorials triggered by the first entry to any given scene.

Just to note, I believe it should be possible to make it one tutorial that outlines the features of a scene, then (after clicking a "Next >" button) loads another scene. So this could be made to give a full tour of the complete KSC and all scenes.

Other than that, I agree with the points about very low discoverability.

There wasn't much actually announced about the admin building. They talked about mk3 parts and spaceplane plus and basically just said there was an admin building. They did share some information on it though. Hold on a sec and I'll find it .

Info shared in the KerbalCast interview with Maxmaps a approximate order (kerbal_Podcast_016):

2:00 - "Almost as big as .24 currencies". Maxmaps says there are the three currencies (Reputation, Science, Money) and there is no cohesiveness or interplay between them and that's "not particularly cool".

2:40 - The admin building includes new systems that makes your play style more customizable. It adds a lot of interaction between the 3 currencies.

3:00 - The admin building is mostly the focus of .25

3:15 - "There are 2 new systems being added that are going to modify how you play" - one announced next week, one announced at QA. "It's something that no mod whatsoever has done to this point" - it wasn't even considered anywhere. You won't run in to it if you play really well.

4:00 - It's somewhere around 90% of the framework for a big feature going to be added to .26.

4:15 - Helipad is basically just to land on.

5:00 - talks about their beginnings in career

6:00 - intetragion of spaceplane+. Hugo built a "whole bunch" of mk3 parts, and SpacePlane+ is added.

End of the first interview segment and the majority of announcements,

29:20 - Contracts with modders and updating of rules - Asking for donations OUTSIDE of KSP is fine, no "adds", make it easy to say no to data gathering. Keep gathered data closed. Data gathering would be fine if they knew everyone was going to play nice, but they don't and they don't want excuses or possibilities of things going wrong.

48:00 - About an end game goal - There is a signed document of what it should look like at the end, but they have lots of wiggle room and room for extra things added. (More or less.)

54:00 - Maxmaps background with career and joining SQUAD! Just listen I'm not summarizing this.

That's about it. Hope this helps! Please tell me if I missed anything of importance and I'll add it.
